Blog.post: For my first blog, I thought I'd do a quick thought I have about fatherhood. It's my theory on how to be a good dad and it's based on being a high school teacher and seeing how 17 year olds differ because of their dads. It's a simple philosophy: kids are like piggy banks. While they are young and don't know any better (and actually like being with mom and dad) dad's need to deposit as much as they can time wise and emotionally. My rule: every time they laugh, it's $1 in the bank. Because every day, your child will withdraw funds from the piggy banks and as teens, the take a lot out. The idea is to make sure there is always something in the bank. It may seem simple, but I honestly believe that if you put in a ton of time up front, it will get you through those teenage years.

The one issue that has troubled me the most lately is the idea of gay marriage. One part of me is fundamentally oppossed to it while the other part of me figurese, "who really cares?" In fact, the last time I wrote seriously about this is sided for gay marriage. I'm changing my mind. There are two arguments I haven't heard in the debate that has done this. First, opponents of the Gay Marriage Amendment say it should be up to the states, not the federal government. Well, they're forgetting an important part of the Amendment process which is that after the Amendment passes Congress, it must be passed by 3/4ths of the state legislatures. Imagine that, honest debate within every state of the Union. In fact, the original intent of our Founding Fathers like James Madison was the have the Constitution as the document that represents all Americans, thus the phrase in the Constitution that caused a lot of controversy at the time, "We the People," not, "We the States." Second, maybe the long term affects of SSM would be detrimental. Let's look at two studies. The urlLink first shows how illegitamacy rates increase in places SSM are allowed. The urlLink second study shows how economic and social factors decline in homes without a father. Now, I know the first is a blog and the second is from a Catholic site which some may think are unscientific or unreliable places to site studies, but I'm willing to bet places like Harvard would find the same thing. Either way, if this is true, though there will always be excepts, by and large we would have to assume that if we allow SSM the illegitamacy rate in the US would increase which would increase poverty, crime, and illiteracy. Unless shown otherwise, I don't think I can support gay marriage anymore.
